bibl.title: Letter from R.S. Webster to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1940

div1.p: Webster encloses the Cuban railway plans which are near Camps Columbia and Lazear, and gives some additional information concerning the various sites.

div1.head: Letter from R.S. Webster to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1940
div1.opener:
FERROCARRILES UNIDOS DE LA HABANA
Y ALMACENES DE REGLA, LIMITADA
COMPAÑIA INTERNACIONAL
------
Regla Warehouses.
VIAS Y OBRAS
----
HABANA, August 22nd, 1940.- NUM. -
Philip S. Hench, M.D.
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of August 14th, relative
to the location of “Camp Lazear” on the San José farm at
Quemados (Marianao) I am encloasing the old plans that I
have been able to locate in our file.

The Marianao Line was constructed and put in ope-
ration on July 19th, 1863 and the branch from Quemados to
La Playa was opened for service in 1884.-

The part of large scale plan showing the connec-
tions at Quemados, Military Store Houses (Almacenes) and
a short section of the Playa branch was made in 1906.

The connection between Quemados and the Playa
branch and the Quarter-Master's Stores (Almacenes) were
constructed in 1898 by Col. C.C. Fitz Gerald then an offi-
cer in the Army of Occupation of the First Cuban Inter-
vention.

Col. Fitz Gerald now resides in Havana with Con-
tracting offices in the Edificio Metropolitana.

The small topographical plan of the Playa Branch
was made in 1881 according to our records for obtaining
the concession for this branch.

The large general plan is of unknown date but was
copied from some old plan in 1906 on which was traced the
location of Insular Railway. You will note that the con-
nection between Quemados and the Playa Branch is not shown
although it existed in 1906.

The smaller general plan of Marianao also of un-
known date but evidently made sometime during the 1880.

The United States Army during the first Interven-
- 2 -
tion made maps of the whole Island and I am quite cer-
tain detailed plans of Camp Columbia which possibly
you could obtain from the War Department in Washington.

I well remember having been in what was repre-
sented to me to be the huts of Camp Lazear in 1906
which as I remember consisted each of one small one
room wooden building with screened windows and a double
screen door entrance.

At that time I was not personally very much in-
terested in Yellow Fever, although in the Fall of 1906
there were some cases in Havana, as I considered myself
immune having had the fever at the village of San Sebas-
tian in Vera Cruz State (Mexico) in 1903.

I am sorry that I havent located a map such as
you desire but should I do so I will forward it to you.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, R S Webster
Divisional Engineer.-
P.S.-. I am also enclosing a plan of Havana and
vicinity showing the location of Camp Columbia.
RSW
RSW/RA
